profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Bozrah, Conn., October 26, 1788; moved to New York with his parents, who settled on a farm near Hoosick in 1796; attended the common schools; taught school; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1809 and commenced practice in Plattsburgh in 1810; master in chancery and circuit judge in 1811; served in the War of 1812; aide-de-camp to Gen. Benjamin Mooers and division judge advocate with rank of colonel; elected to the Seventeenth Congress (March 4, 1821-March 3, 1823); was not a candidate for renomination in 1822; judge of the fourth judicial district of New York 1823-1828; moved to Saratoga Springs, Saratoga County, N.Y., in October 1828; chancellor of the State of New York from 1828 to 1848, when the office of chancellor was abolished; unsuccessful candidate for election as Governor in 1848; appointed as an Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court by President Tyler in 1844, but was not confirmed by the Senate; died in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., November 27, 1867; interment in Greenridge Cemetery.

note.content: One of two elected to represent the 12th district.

researchRecord.name: ca. 1788-1867, 6 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Personal and business letters of Reuben Hyde Walworth; letters of his first wife Maria Ketchum Averill Walworth; letters of his second wife, Sarah Hardin Walworth. Papers of Ellen Hardin Walworth (1832-1915), including scrapbooks on the D.A.R., Mothers' Club, and Women's War Relief during the Spanish-American War; also monographs on patriotic topics, diaries, and poetry. Transcripts of the trial of Francis Walworth for the murder of his father Mansfield Walworth in defense of his mother, Ellen Hardin Walworth. Civil War letters of members of the Hardin family of Indiana and Kentucky, including Lemuel Hardin who fought for the Confederacy and Martin Hardin who fought for the Union.

researchRecord.name: 1827-1866, 18 volumes.
researchRecord.description: The volumes are from when Reuben Walworth was a chancellor and circuit judge. The volumes contain the following: testimony in the case of Troy Iron & Nail Factory vs. Erastus Corning et. al., 1854-64; opinions in chancery, 1829-30; opinions in Court of Errors, 1827-46, including record of chancellor's opinions, votes of court, and official correspondence with Governor Martin Van Buren; notes of case of Troy Iron & Nail Factory vs. Erastus Corning, John F. Winstow, and James Norner, in equity, 1866; and ms. of chapters 5-26 of book by Walworth on the lives of the chancellors of New York State.
